nodes.caption: On August 2, 1956, John Coolidge writes to the Director General of Antiquities and Museums in Ankara, indicating the museum's interest in resurrecting its work in classical archaeology via an excavation in Turkey, led by George M.A. Hanfmann.

In this handwritten letter, dated June 1957, from George M.A. Hanfmann to John Coolidge, he reports that applications for permits to excavate in Sardis have been filed by he and A. Henry Detweiler, of the American School of Oriental Research, co-sponsor of the expedition.
John Coolidge reports news of the filing of the application permits to dig at Sardis to McGeorge Bundy, Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, in July of 1957.
Telegram from George M.A. Hanfmann to John Coolidge announcing the discovery of the Lydian city of Sardis after "two months' search."
Proposed and actual budget for the 1958 season at Sardis, the first of the expedition
Proposed budget for the 1959 season at Sardis, the second of the expedition.

George M. A. Hanfmann's correspondence from the field was often condensed into newsletters for the Fogg Museum staff. In this one from 1958, the "thrilling" discovery of a sherd bearing a Lydian inscription is described.
This newsletter details early work and discoveries in Sardis during the inaugural season.
George M.A. Hanfmann wrote an article for the Boston Globe entitled "Ancient Gamblers Used Dice of Baked Clay," published on October 15, 1958.
John Washeba and the bronze cauldron at the compound, 1959

nodes.title: Exhibitions
nodes.content:
The discoveries at the Archaeological Exploration of Sardis inspired many exhibitions throughout the years, even though items excavated from the site cannot leave Turkey. Explore the creative ways the expedition has been presented to the public by viewing materials from:

"Gods and Heroes: Baroque Images of Antiquity" on display at the Wildenstein Gallery in New York City from October 30, 1968 to January 4, 1969

"Twenty Five Years of Discovery at Sardis, 1958–1983" on display at the Fogg Museum from November 3, 1983 to January 8, 1984

"City of Sardis: Approaches in Graphic Recording," on display at the Fogg Museum from August 23, 2003 to January 18, 2004

nodes.caption: This is a promotional pamphlet from the exhibition "Gods and Heroes: Baroque Images of Antiquity," held at the Wildenstein Gallery in New York City from October 30, 1968 to January 4, 1969. The exhibition of loans from private and public collections examined the artistic relationship between the seventeenth century and the classical tradition.

A poster advertising "Gods and Heroes: Baroque Images of Antiquity," held at the Wildenstein Gallery in New York City from October 30, 1968 to January 4, 1969. The exhibition of loans from private and public collections examined the artistic relationship between the seventeenth century and the classical tradition.

An invitation to the opening of "Gods and Heroes: Baroque Images of Antiquity," held at the Wildenstein Gallery in New York City from October 30, 1968 to January 4, 1969. The exhibition of loans from private and public collections examined the artistic relationship between the seventeenth century and the classical tradition.

An article published in the New York Times, entitled "A New Group Digs In to help Have a City of Long Ago Dug Up," June 2, 1968. George M.A. Hanfmann solicited prominent members of New York's high society to host dinners to promote the exhibition "Gods and Heroes: Baroque Images of Antiquity," and raise awareness for the Archaeological Exploration of Sardis.

This article from the Harvard Crimson describes the history of Sardis and reports on the current—in 1984—conditions at the site. The article, "Sardis Reveals its Riches," was published on January 5, 1984 to coincide with the exhibition "Twenty Five Years of Discovery at Sardis, 1958–1983" then on view at the Fogg Museum.

The cover catalogue from the exhibition "Twenty Five Years of Discovery at Sardis, 1958–1983," which was on display at the Fogg Museum from November 3, 1983 to January 8, 1984. This exhibition highlighted the discoveries and innovations made at the site since 1958.

An invitation to the opening reception for "Twenty Five Years of Discovery at Sardis, 1958–1983" on November 3, 1983 at the Fogg Museum. The exhibition featured drawings, watercolors, casts, ceramics, coins, and scientific samples from the Fogg's collection and loans from Yale to illustrate the ongoing excavation and research at Sardis.
An article from the Harvard University Gazette titled "Artists' Visions/Versions of Ancient Sardis" about the exhibition "City of Sardis: Approaches in Graphic Recording" at the Fogg Museum.

The brochure from the XVI International Congress of Classical Archaeology, with an invitation to view the exhibition "City of Sardis: Approaches in Graphic Recording" at the Fogg Museum on view from August 23, 2003 to January 18, 2004. The exhibition used drawings, architectural renderings, digital reconstructions, and maps to demonstrate the ways documentation of Sardis site had changed.
John Coolidge, Director of the Fogg Museum from 1948–1968, was a staunch supporter of Sardis and the work of George M.A. Hanfmann.
Newspaper clipping featuring John Washeba, headed to Sardis to perform object conservation, 1959.
